page.title: 16LIVESTOCK KEPT AT GRASSMOOR.
page.content: The allotments at Grassmoor are used to house a variety of livestock. Some men keep pigeons which are for racing. One man was racing his pigeons all the way from France. One man has a few geese and some goslings. Quite a lot of people kept hens to provide fresh eggs. Some of them breed their own chickens. There is a large aviary on the allotment made from a garden shed with a covered flight pen at the side. Most of the birds kept are zebra finches and goldfinches. The others were cockateels, one of which was breeding. The allotments are also popular with wild birds which find a large supply of food readily available. There are plenty of taps provided to supply water for the plants and animals, including an old goat which is tethered on one plot of land.
